FedNS: A Fast Sketching Newton-Type Algorithm for Federated Learning

Jian Li1, Yong Liu2, Wei Wang3, Haoran Wu3, Weiping Wang1 Corresponding author
Abstract

Recent Newton-type federated learning algorithms have demonstrated linear convergence with respect to the communication rounds. However, communicating Hessian matrices is often unfeasible due to their quadratic communication complexity. In this paper, we introduce a novel approach to tackle this issue while still achieving fast convergence rates. Our proposed method, named as Federated Newton Sketch methods (FedNS), approximates the centralized Newton‚Äôs method by communicating the sketched square-root Hessian instead of the exact Hessian. To enhance communication efficiency, we reduce the sketch size to match the effective dimension of the Hessian matrix. We provide convergence analysis based on statistical learning for the federated Newton sketch approaches. Specifically, our approaches reach super-linear convergence rates w.r.t. the communication rounds for the first time. We validate the effectiveness of our algorithms through various experiments, which coincide with our theoretical findings.

Introduction

Due to the huge potential in terms of privacy protection and reducing computational costs, Federated Learning (FL) (Koneƒçn·ª≥ et¬†al. 2016; McMahan et¬†al. 2017; Li et¬†al. 2020a; Wei et¬†al. 2021, 2022; Li, Liu, and Wang 2024) becomes a promising framework for handling large-scale tasks. In federated learning, a key problem is to achieve a tradeoff between the convergence rate and the communication burdens.

First-order optimization algorithms have achieved great success in federated learning, including FedAvg (LocalSGD) (McMahan et¬†al. 2017) and FedProx (Li et¬†al. 2020a). These methods communicate the first-order information rather than the data across local machines, which protect the privacy training data and allow the data heterogeneity to some extent. Despite recent efforts and progress on the convergence analysis (Li et¬†al. 2020b, c; Karimireddy et¬†al. 2020; Pathak and Wainwright 2020; Glasgow, Yuan, and Ma 2022) and the generalization analysis (Mohri, Sivek, and Suresh 2019; Li, Liu, and Wang 2023b, a; Su, Xu, and Yang 2021; Yuan et¬†al. 2022) of FedAvg and FedProx, the convergence rate of first-order federated algorithms is still slow, i.e., a sublinear converge rate ùí™‚Äã(1/t)ùí™1ùë°\mathcal{O}(1/t), where tùë°t is the communication rounds.

In the traditional centralized learning, with some mild conditions, second-order optimal algorithms (Boyd, Boyd, and Vandenberghe 2004; Bottou, Curtis, and Nocedal 2018), for example (quasi) Newton‚Äôs methods, can achieve at least a linear convergence rate. The compute of inverse Hessian is time consuming, and thus many classic approximate Newton‚Äôs methods are proposed, including BFGS (Broyden 1970), L-BFGS (Liu and Nocedal 1989), inexact Newton (Dembo, Eisenstat, and Steihaug 1982), Gauss-Newton (Schraudolph 2002) and Newton sketch (Pilanci and Wainwright 2017). However, if we directly apply Newton‚Äôs method to federated learning, the communication complexity of sharing local Hessian matrices is overwhelming.

Indeed, first-order algorithms characterize low communication burdens but slow convergence rates, while Newton‚Äôs methods lead to fast convergence rates but with high communication complexity. To take advantage of both first-order and second-order algorithms, we propose a federated Newton sketch method, named FedNS, which shares both first-order and second-order information across devices, i.e., local gradients and sketched square-root Hessian. Using line search strategy and adaptive learning rates, we devise a dimension-efficient approach FedNDES. We then study the convergence properties for the proposed algorithms. We conclude with experiments on publicly available datasets that complement our theoretical results, exhibiting both computational and statistical benefits. We leave proofs in the appendix111Full version: https://lijian.ac.cn/files/2024/FedNS.pdf
Code: https://github.com/superlj666/FedNS. We summarize our contributions as below:

1) On the algorithmic front. We propose two fast second-order federated algorithms, which improve the approximation of the centralized Newton‚Äôs method while the communication costs are favorable due to the small sketch size. Specifically, using line search and adaptive step-sizes in Algorithm 2, the sketch size can be reduced to the effective dimension of the Hessian matrix.

2) On the statistical front. Drawing upon the established outcomes from the centralized sketching Newton literature (Pilanci and Wainwright 2017; Lacotte, Wang, and Pilanci 2021), we furnish convergence analysis for two federated Newton sketching algorithms: FedNS and its line-search variant FedNDES. These methodologies delineate not only super-linear convergence rates but also entail a small sketch size, corresponding to the effective dimension of the Hessian in the case of FedNDES. Note that the proposed algorithms achieve super-linear convergence rates while upholding a reasonable level of communication complexity.

Related Work

FedAvg and FedProx. FedAvg and FedProx only share local gradients of the size MùëÄM and the communication complexity is ùí™‚Äã(M)ùí™ùëÄ\mathcal{O}(M), where MùëÄM is the dimension of feature space. The convergence properties of FedAvg and FedProx have been well-studied in (Li et¬†al. 2020c, a; Su, Xu, and Yang 2021), of which the iteration complexity is T=ùí™‚Äã(1/Œ¥)ùëáùí™1ùõøT=\mathcal{O}(1/\delta) to obtain some Œ¥ùõø\delta-accurate solution.

Newton sketch. Newton sketch was proposed in (Pilanci and Wainwright 2017) to accelerate the compute of Newton‚Äôs methods. It has been further extended, for example, Newton-LESS (Derezinski et¬†al. 2021) employed leverage scores to sparsify the Gaussian sketching matrix and (Lacotte and Pilanci 2020; Lacotte, Wang, and Pilanci 2021) proved the sketch size can be as small as the effective dimension of the Hessian matrix. With the sketching Newton‚Äôs methods, the communication complexity is ùí™‚Äã(k‚ÄãM)ùí™ùëòùëÄ\mathcal{O}(kM), where kùëòk is the sketch size. In some cases, it leads to a super-linear convergence T=ùí™‚Äã(log‚Å°(log‚Å°1/Œ¥))ùëáùí™1ùõøT=\mathcal{O}(\log(\log 1/\delta)) for a Œ¥ùõø\delta-accurate solution.

Newton-type federated algorithms. DistributedNewton (Ghosh, Maity, and Mazumdar 2020) and LocalNewton (Gupta et¬†al. 2021) perform Newton‚Äôs method instead of SGD on local machines to accelerate the convergence of local models. FedNew (Elgabli et¬†al. 2022) utilized one pass ADMM on local machines to calculating local directions and approximate Newton method to update the global model. FedNL (Safaryan et¬†al. 2022) sended the compressed local Hessian updates to global server and performed Newton step globally. Based on eigendecomposition of the local Hessian matrices, SHED (Fabbro et¬†al. 2022) incrementally updated eigenvector-eigenvalue pairs to the global server and recovered the Hessian to use Newton method.

A standard federated learning system consists of a global server and mùëöm local compute nodes. Different types of randomized sketches lead to different the sketch times (Lacotte, Wang, and Pilanci 2021), i.e., ùí™‚Äã(N‚ÄãM‚Äãk)ùí™ùëÅùëÄùëò\mathcal{O}(NMk) for sub-Gaussian embeddings, ùí™‚Äã(N‚ÄãM‚Äãlog‚Å°k)ùí™ùëÅùëÄùëò\mathcal{O}(NM\log k) for subspace randomized Hadamard transform (SRHT), and ùí™‚Äã(nnz‚Äã(ùëØ~ùíü,t))ùí™nnzsubscript~ùëØùíüùë°\mathcal{O}(\textbf{nnz}(\widetilde{{\boldsymbol{H}}}_{\mathcal{D},t})) for the sparse Johnson-Lindenstrauss transform (SJLT). For the SJLT, only one non-zero entry exists per column, which causes much faster sketch time but requires a larger subspace. Throughout this work, we focus on the SRHT because it achieves a tradeoff between fast sketch time and small sketch dimension (Ailon and Chazelle 2006).

There are various examples for the optimization problem (1) where the regularization term is ŒªùúÜ\lambda-strongly convex and partial sketched square-root Hessian S‚Äã‚àá2L‚Äã(ùíò)ùëÜsuperscript‚àá2ùêøùíòS\nabla^{2}L({\boldsymbol{w}}) is amenable to fast computation. For example, the widely used ridge regression and regularized logistic regression. More examples are referred to Section 3.1 (Lacotte, Wang, and Pilanci 2021).

Federated Learning with Newton‚Äôs Methods

To reduce the communication burdens in FedNewton, we propose a communication-efficient algorithm to approximate the global Hessian matrix. Based on the Newton Sketch (Pilanci and Wainwright 2017), we devise an efficient Newton sketch method for federated learning, which performs an approximate local Hessians using a randomly projected or sub-sampled Hessian on the local workers. Then, it summarizes the local Hessian matrices to approximate the global Hessian matrix and then performs Newton‚Äôs method on the approximate global Hessian matrix.

Federated Newton‚Äôs Method (FedNewton)

To approximate the global model fùíü,ŒªsubscriptùëìùíüùúÜf_{\mathcal{D},\lambda} well, the federated learning algorithms usually share local information to the other clients, i.e. first-order gradient information in FedAvg and FedProx. We consider using both first-order and second-order information to characterize the exact solution of (1) on the entire dataset ùíüùíü\mathcal{D}.

Noting that, both local gradients and Hessians in (3) can be summarized up to the global gradient and Hessian, respectively. This motivates us to summarize local gradients and Hessians to conduct federated Newton‚Äôs method (FedNewton)

Complexity Analysis. Before the iterations, the computation of feature mapping on any local machine consumes ùí™‚Äã(nj‚ÄãM‚Äãd)ùí™subscriptùëõùëóùëÄùëë\mathcal{O}({n_{j}}Md) time. We formally introduce the general framework for Federated Newton Sketch (FedNS) in Algorithm 1. Complexity Analysis. Before the iterations, the computation of feature mapping on any local machine consumes ùí™‚Äã(nj‚ÄãM‚Äãd)ùí™subscriptùëõùëóùëÄùëë\mathcal{O}({n_{j}}Md) time. On the jùëój-th local worker, the sketching time is ùí™‚Äã(nj‚ÄãM‚Äãlog‚Å°k)ùí™subscriptùëõùëóùëÄùëò\mathcal{O}(n_{j}M\log k) for SRHT, while it is ùí™‚Äã(nj‚ÄãM‚Äãk)ùí™subscriptùëõùëóùëÄùëò\mathcal{O}(n_{j}Mk) for classic sub-Gaussian embeddings. On the global server, the time complexity of FedNS is ùí™‚Äã(m‚Äãk‚ÄãM2+M3)ùí™ùëöùëòsuperscriptùëÄ2superscriptùëÄ3\mathcal{O}(mkM^{2}+M^{3}) to obtain the global sketch Hessian and its inverse. Nevertheless, FedNS reduces the communication burdens from ùí™‚Äã(M2)ùí™superscriptùëÄ2\mathcal{O}(M^{2}) to ùí™‚Äã(k‚ÄãM)ùí™ùëòùëÄ\mathcal{O}(kM). Overall, FedNS not only speedup the local computations, but more importantly reduce the communication costs. The total computational complexity is ùí™‚Äã(maxj‚àà[m]‚Å°nj‚ÄãM‚Äãd+nj‚ÄãM‚Äãt‚Äãlog‚Å°k+m‚Äãk‚ÄãM2‚Äãt+M3‚Äãt)ùí™subscriptùëódelimited-[]ùëösubscriptùëõùëóùëÄùëësubscriptùëõùëóùëÄùë°ùëòùëöùëòsuperscriptùëÄ2ùë°superscriptùëÄ3ùë°\mathcal{O}(\max_{j\in[m]}{n_{j}}Md+n_{j}Mt\log k+mkM^{2}t+M^{3}t). More importantly, the communication complexity is reduced from ùí™‚Äã(M2‚Äãt)ùí™superscriptùëÄ2ùë°\mathcal{O}(M^{2}t) in FedNewton to ùí™‚Äã(k‚ÄãM‚Äãt)ùí™ùëòùëÄùë°\mathcal{O}(kMt) in FedNS. The sketch Newton method leads to a super-linear convergence rate t=ùí™‚Äã(log‚Å°(1/Œ¥))ùë°ùí™1ùõøt=\mathcal{O}(\log(1/\delta)) for Œ¥ùõø\delta-approximation guarantee (Pilanci and Wainwright 2017; Lacotte, Wang, and Pilanci 2021). Note that, from Theorem 1, since k=Œ©‚Äã(M)ùëòŒ©ùëÄk=\Omega(M) for FedNS, just using sketching without line-search does not reduce communication cost. We then present line-search step based sketching Federated Newton method, which can guarantee smaller communication costs.

Federated Newton‚Äôs Method with Dimension-Efficient Sketching (FedNDES)

From the theoretical results in the next section, the sketch size for FedNS is k‚âÉMsimilar-to-or-equalsùëòùëÄk\simeq M to achieve a super-linear convergence rate, which is still too expensive when MùëÄM is large to approximate the kernel. Since the communication is determined by the sketch size, we devise a dimension-efficient federated Newton sketch approach (FedNDES), shown in Algorithm 2 to reduce the sketch size, based on the Newton sketch with backtracking line (Armijo) search (Boyd, Boyd, and Vandenberghe 2004; Nocedal and Wright 2006; Pilanci and Wainwright 2017; Lacotte, Wang, and Pilanci 2021). Backtracking line search begins with an initial step-size Œºùúá\mu and backtracks until the adjusted linear estimate overestimates the loss function. For more information refer to (Boyd, Boyd, and Vandenberghe 2004).

Different from FedNS, Algorithm 2 applies the two phases updates with different sketch sizes m¬Ø1subscript¬Øùëö1\overline{m}_{1} and m¬Ø2subscript¬Øùëö2\overline{m}_{2}. The following theoretical results illustrate both these two sketch sizes depend on the effective dimension that is much smaller than MùëÄM and NùëÅN. The approximate Newton decrement Œª~‚Äã(ùíòt)~ùúÜsubscriptùíòùë°\tilde{\lambda}({\boldsymbol{w}}_{t}) is used as an exit condition and the threshold for the adaptive sketch sizes to guarantee smaller iterations and sketch sizes.

Complexity Analysis. Since the compute of approximate global Hessian and the inverse of it dominate the training time, the total computational complexity for FedNDES is similar to FedNS that is ùí™‚Äã(maxj‚àà[m]‚Å°nj‚ÄãM‚Äãd+nj‚ÄãM‚Äãt‚Äãlog‚Å°k+m‚Äãk‚ÄãM2‚Äãt+M3‚Äãt)ùí™subscriptùëódelimited-[]ùëösubscriptùëõùëóùëÄùëësubscriptùëõùëóùëÄùë°ùëòùëöùëòsuperscriptùëÄ2ùë°superscriptùëÄ3ùë°\mathcal{O}(\max_{j\in[m]}{n_{j}}Md+n_{j}Mt\log k+mkM^{2}t+M^{3}t). However, the communication complexity ùí™‚Äã(k‚ÄãM‚Äãt)ùí™ùëòùëÄùë°\mathcal{O}(kMt) is reduced owing to a smaller sketch size in FedNDES. The sketch size is k‚âÉMsimilar-to-or-equalsùëòùëÄk\simeq M for FedNS, while it is k‚âÉTr‚Äã(ùëØ~ùíü,t‚Äã(ùëØ~ùíü,t+Œª‚ÄãI)‚àí1)similar-to-or-equalsùëòTrsubscript~ùëØùíüùë°superscriptsubscript~ùëØùíüùë°ùúÜùêº1k\simeq\text{Tr}(\widetilde{{\boldsymbol{H}}}_{\mathcal{D},t}(\widetilde{{\boldsymbol{H}}}_{\mathcal{D},t}+\lambda I)^{-1}) for FedNDES that is much smaller than MùëÄM. Smaller sketch size makes the Newton methods practical for multiple communications in federated learning settings. Meanwhile, even with the smaller sketch size, FedNDES can still achieve the super-linear convergence rate t=ùí™‚Äã(log‚Å°log‚Å°(1/Œ¥))ùë°ùí™1ùõøt=\mathcal{O}(\log\log(1/\delta)) for Œ¥ùõø\delta-approximation solution.

Theoretical Guarantees

Before the generalization analysis for algorithms, we start with some notations and assumptions.

Assumption 1 (Twice differentiable and convex).

The loss function and regularity function ‚Ñì,Œ±:‚Ñùd‚Üí‚Ñù:‚Ñìùõº‚Üísuperscript‚Ñùùëë‚Ñù\ell,\alpha:\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R} are both closed and twice differentiable convex functions and ‚àá2Œ±‚Äã(ùê∞)‚™∞Idsucceeds-or-equalssuperscript‚àá2ùõºùê∞subscriptùêºùëë\nabla^{2}\alpha({\boldsymbol{w}})\succeq I_{d}.

Assumption 2 (Strongly convextiy and smoothness).

Let Œ≥=Œªmin‚Äã(‚àá2L‚Äã(ùê∞))ùõæsubscriptùúÜminsuperscript‚àá2ùêøùê∞\gamma=\lambda_{\text{min}}(\nabla^{2}L({\boldsymbol{w}})) be the minimum eigenvalue and Œ≤=Œªmax‚Äã(‚àá2L‚Äã(ùê∞))ùõΩsubscriptùúÜmaxsuperscript‚àá2ùêøùê∞\beta=\lambda_{\text{max}}(\nabla^{2}L({\boldsymbol{w}})) be the maximum eigenvalue of the Hessian.

In the standard analysis of Newton‚Äôs method, Œ≥ùõæ\gamma and Œ≤ùõΩ\beta are commonly used to measure the strong convexity and smoothness of the objective function LùêøL (Pilanci and Wainwright 2017).

Assumption 3 (Lipschitz continuous Hessian).

The Hessian map is Lipschitz continuous with modulus Gùê∫G, i.e., ‚Äñ‚àá2L‚Äã(ùê∞)‚àí‚àá2L‚Äã(ùê∞‚Ä≤)‚Äñ‚â§G‚Äã‚Äñùê∞‚àíùê∞‚Ä≤‚Äñ2.normsuperscript‚àá2ùêøùê∞superscript‚àá2ùêøsuperscriptùê∞‚Ä≤ùê∫subscriptnormùê∞superscriptùê∞‚Ä≤2\|\nabla^{2}L({\boldsymbol{w}})-\nabla^{2}L({\boldsymbol{w}}^{\prime})\|\leq G\|{\boldsymbol{w}}-{\boldsymbol{w}}^{\prime}\|_{2}.

The above assumptions are standard conditions for both convex and non-convex optimization. Under these conditions, with the appropriate initialization ‚Äñùíò‚àíùíòùíü,Œª‚Äñ‚â§Œ≥2‚ÄãGnormùíòsubscriptùíòùíüùúÜùõæ2ùê∫\|{\boldsymbol{w}}-{\boldsymbol{w}}_{\mathcal{D},\lambda}\|\leq\frac{\gamma}{2G}, the Newton approach can guarantee a quadratic convergence (Boyd, Boyd, and Vandenberghe 2004). Let ùíòtsubscriptùíòùë°{\boldsymbol{w}}_{t} be the federated Newton model defined in FedNS or FedNDES, and ùíò‚àósuperscriptùíò{\boldsymbol{w}}^{*} be the target model. It holds the following error decomposition

‚Äñùíòt‚àíùíò‚àó‚Äñ2‚â§‚Äñùíòt‚àíùíòùíü,Œª‚Äñ2‚èüfederated error+‚Äñùíòùíü,Œª‚àíùíò‚àó‚Äñ2‚èücentralized excess risk,subscriptnormsubscriptùíòùë°superscriptùíò2subscript‚èüsubscriptnormsubscriptùíòùë°subscriptùíòùíüùúÜ2federated errorsubscript‚èüsubscriptnormsubscriptùíòùíüùúÜsuperscriptùíò2centralized excess risk\displaystyle\|{\boldsymbol{w}}_{t}-{\boldsymbol{w}}^{*}\|_{2}\leq\underbrace{\|{\boldsymbol{w}}_{t}-{\boldsymbol{w}}_{\mathcal{D},\lambda}\|_{2}}_{\text{federated error}}+\underbrace{\|{\boldsymbol{w}}_{\mathcal{D},\lambda}-{\boldsymbol{w}}^{*}\|_{2}}_{\text{centralized excess risk}}, (8)

where ùíòùíü,ŒªsubscriptùíòùíüùúÜ{\boldsymbol{w}}_{\mathcal{D},\lambda} is the centralized ERM model on the training data ùíüùíü\mathcal{D}. Since the centralized excess risk L‚Äã(ùíòùíü,Œª)‚àíL‚Äã(ùíò‚àó)ùêøsubscriptùíòùíüùúÜùêøsuperscriptùíòL({\boldsymbol{w}}_{\mathcal{D},\lambda})-L({\boldsymbol{w}}^{*}) is standard in statistical learning (Bartlett and Mendelson 2002; Caponnetto and De¬†Vito 2007), we focused on the federated error term.

Convergence Analysis for FedNS

Theorem 1 in (Pilanci and Wainwright 2017) provided the convergence analysis for centralized Newton sketch in (4). Based on it, we present on the generalization analysis for federated Newton sketch in Algorithm 1.

Theorem 1 (Convergence guarantees of FedNS).

Let Œ¥‚àà(0,1)ùõø01\delta\in(0,1). Under Assumptions 1, 2, 3, FedNS updates in Algorithm 1 based on an appropriate initialization ‚Äñùê∞0‚àíùê∞ùíü,Œª‚Äñ2‚â§Œ¥‚ÄãŒ≥8‚ÄãGsubscriptnormsubscriptùê∞0subscriptùê∞ùíüùúÜ2ùõøùõæ8ùê∫\|{\boldsymbol{w}}_{0}-{\boldsymbol{w}}_{\mathcal{D},\lambda}\|_{2}\leq\frac{\delta\gamma}{8G}. Using the iteration-dependent sketching accuracy œµ=1log‚Å°(1+t)italic-œµ11ùë°\epsilon=\frac{1}{\log(1+t)} and sketch size k=Œ©‚Äã(M)ùëòŒ©ùëÄk=\Omega(M), with the probability at least 1‚àíc1‚Äãe‚àíc2‚Äãk‚Äãœµ21subscriptùëê1superscriptùëísubscriptùëê2ùëòsuperscriptitalic-œµ21-c_{1}e^{-c_{2}k\epsilon^{2}}, we have

‚Äñùíòt‚àíùíòùíü,Œª‚Äñ2‚â§1log‚Å°(1+t)‚ÄãŒ≤Œ≥‚Äã‚Äñùíòt‚àí1‚àíùíòùíü,Œª‚Äñ2.subscriptnormsubscriptùíòùë°subscriptùíòùíüùúÜ211ùë°ùõΩùõæsubscriptnormsubscriptùíòùë°1subscriptùíòùíüùúÜ2\displaystyle\|{\boldsymbol{w}}_{t}-{\boldsymbol{w}}_{\mathcal{D},\lambda}\|_{2}\leq\frac{1}{\log(1+t)}\frac{\beta}{\gamma}\|{\boldsymbol{w}}_{t-1}-{\boldsymbol{w}}_{\mathcal{D},\lambda}\|_{2}.

This guarantee a super-linear convergence rate, since limt‚Üí‚àû‚Äñùê∞t‚àíùê∞ùíü,Œª‚Äñ2‚Äñùê∞t‚àí1‚àíùê∞ùíü,Œª‚Äñ2=0.subscript‚Üíùë°subscriptnormsubscriptùê∞ùë°subscriptùê∞ùíüùúÜ2subscriptnormsubscriptùê∞ùë°1subscriptùê∞ùíüùúÜ20\lim_{t\to\infty}\frac{\|{\boldsymbol{w}}_{t}-{\boldsymbol{w}}_{\mathcal{D},\lambda}\|_{2}}{\|{\boldsymbol{w}}_{t-1}-{\boldsymbol{w}}_{\mathcal{D},\lambda}\|_{2}}=0. Here, ùê∞ùíü,Œªsubscriptùê∞ùíüùúÜ{\boldsymbol{w}}_{\mathcal{D},\lambda} is the centralized model on ùíüùíü\mathcal{D} and ùê∞tsubscriptùê∞ùë°{\boldsymbol{w}}_{t} is the federated model trained in Algorithm 1.

The above theorem shows that, depending on the structure of the problem Œ≥,Œ≤ùõæùõΩ\gamma,\beta, FedSN achieves the super-linear convergence rate using a sufficient sketch size k‚â≥Mgreater-than-or-equivalent-toùëòùëÄk\gtrsim M. And thus, the communication complexity in each iteration is at least ùí™‚Äã(M2)ùí™superscriptùëÄ2\mathcal{O}(M^{2}), the same as FedNewton. There are two drawbacks in Theorem 1: 1) The analysis depends on some constants from the properties of LùêøL, i.e., the curvature constants Œ≥,Œ≤ùõæùõΩ\gamma,\beta and the Lipschitz constant Gùê∫G, which are usually unknown in practice. 2) Theorem 1 requires a initialization condition ‚Äñùíò0‚àíùíòùíü,Œª‚Äñ2‚â§Œ¥‚ÄãŒ≥8‚ÄãGsubscriptnormsubscriptùíò0subscriptùíòùíüùúÜ2ùõøùõæ8ùê∫\|{\boldsymbol{w}}_{0}-{\boldsymbol{w}}_{\mathcal{D},\lambda}\|_{2}\leq\frac{\delta\gamma}{8G}. However, it is hard to find a appropriate start point ùíò0subscriptùíò0{\boldsymbol{w}}_{0} satisfying the condition in practice. 3) The communication complexity of FedSN ùí™‚Äã(k‚ÄãM‚Äãt)ùí™ùëòùëÄùë°\mathcal{O}(kMt) depends on the sketch size, but the communication of current sketch size k‚â≥Mgreater-than-or-equivalent-toùëòùëÄk\gtrsim M is overly expensive.

Convergence Analysis for FedNDES

To derive global convergence free from unknown problem parameters, we require a new condition.

Assumption 4 (Self-concordant function).

A closed convex function œÜ:‚Ñùd‚Üí‚Ñù:ùúë‚Üísuperscript‚Ñùùëë‚Ñù\varphi:\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R} is self-concordant if |œÜ‚Ä≤‚Ä≤‚Ä≤‚Äã(ùê∞)|‚â§2‚Äã(œÜ‚Ä≤‚Ä≤‚Äã(ùê∞))3/2superscriptùúë‚Ä≤‚Ä≤‚Ä≤ùê∞2superscriptsuperscriptùúë‚Ä≤‚Ä≤ùê∞32|\varphi^{\prime\prime\prime}({\boldsymbol{w}})|\leq 2(\varphi^{\prime\prime}({\boldsymbol{w}}))^{3/2}. We assume the loss function ‚Ñì‚Ñì\ell is a convex self-concordant function.

The condition extends to the loss function ‚Ñì:‚Ñùd‚Üí‚Ñù:‚Ñì‚Üísuperscript‚Ñùùëë‚Ñù\ell:\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R} by imposing the requirement on the univariate function œÜùíò,ùùé‚Äã(t):=‚Ñì‚Äã(ùíò+t‚Äãùùé)assignsubscriptùúëùíòùùéùë°‚Ñìùíòùë°ùùé\varphi_{{\boldsymbol{w}},{\boldsymbol{\omega}}}(t):=\ell({\boldsymbol{w}}+t{\boldsymbol{\omega}}) for ùíò,ùùéùíòùùé{\boldsymbol{w}},{\boldsymbol{\omega}} in the domain of ‚Ñì‚Ñì\ell. Examples for self-concordant functions include linear, quadratic functions, negative logarithm, and more examples can be found in (Lacotte, Wang, and Pilanci 2021).

Definition 1 (Empirical effective dimension).

If the regularity term is ŒªùúÜ\lambda-strongly convex, the empirical effective Hessian dimension is defined as d~Œª:=supùê∞‚àà‚ÑãKTr‚Äã(‚àá2L‚Äã(ùíü,ùê∞)‚Äã(‚àá2L‚Äã(ùíü,ùê∞)+Œª‚ÄãI)‚àí1).assignsubscript~ùëëùúÜsubscriptsupremumùê∞subscript‚ÑãùêæTrsuperscript‚àá2ùêøùíüùê∞superscriptsuperscript‚àá2ùêøùíüùê∞ùúÜùêº1\tilde{d}_{\lambda}:=\sup_{{\boldsymbol{w}}\in{\mathcal{H}_{K}}}\text{\rm Tr}\left(\nabla^{2}L(\mathcal{D},{\boldsymbol{w}})(\nabla^{2}L(\mathcal{D},{\boldsymbol{w}})+\lambda I)^{-1}\right).

The empirical effective dimension d~Œªsubscript~ùëëùúÜ\tilde{d}_{\lambda} is substantially smaller than the feature space MùëÄM (Bach 2013; Alaoui and Mahoney 2015). The effective dimension is related to the covariance matrix ‚àá2L‚Äã(ùíü,ùíò)=1N‚Äãœï‚Äã(ùëø)‚ä§‚Äãœï‚Äã(ùëø)superscript‚àá2ùêøùíüùíò1ùëÅitalic-œïsuperscriptùëøtopitalic-œïùëø\nabla^{2}L(\mathcal{D},{\boldsymbol{w}})=\frac{1}{N}\phi({\boldsymbol{X}})^{\top}\phi({\boldsymbol{X}}), which has been well-studied for leverage scores sampling (Rudi et¬†al. 2018; Luise et¬†al. 2019; Chen and Yang 2021) in low-rank approximation. Meanwhile, the expected effective dimension is defined as ùí©‚Äã(Œª)=Tr‚Äã(TK‚Äã(TK+Œª‚ÄãI)‚àí1)ùí©ùúÜTrsubscriptùëáùêæsuperscriptsubscriptùëáùêæùúÜùêº1\mathcal{N}(\lambda)=\text{Tr}(T_{K}(T_{K}+\lambda I)^{-1}) based on the covariance operator TK=‚à´X‚ü®‚ãÖ,œï‚Äã(ùíô)‚ü©‚Äãœï‚Äã(ùíô)‚ÄãùëëœÅX‚Äã(ùíô)subscriptùëáùêæsubscriptùëã‚ãÖitalic-œïùíôitalic-œïùíôdifferential-dsubscriptùúåùëãùíôT_{K}=\int_{X}\langle\cdot,\phi({\boldsymbol{x}})\rangle\phi({\boldsymbol{x}})d\rho_{X}({\boldsymbol{x}}), which has been widely used to prove the optimal learning guarantees for the squared loss (Caponnetto and De¬†Vito 2007; Smale and Zhou 2007).

Without initialization condition, we provide the following convergence guarantee for FedNDES.

Theorem 2 (Convergence guarantees of FedNDES).

Let Œ¥‚àà(0,1)ùõø01\delta\in(0,1) and the sketch matrices be SRHT. Under Assumptions 1, 4, FedNDES updates in Algorithm 2, then with a high probability, the number of iterations TùëáT and the sketch size kùëòk satisfying

T=ùí™‚Äã(log‚Å°log‚Å°(1Œ¥)),k=Œ©‚Äã(d~Œª),formulae-sequenceùëáùí™1ùõøùëòŒ©subscript~ùëëùúÜ\displaystyle T=\mathcal{O}\left(\log\log\left(\frac{1}{\delta}\right)\right),\quad k=\Omega\left(\tilde{d}_{\lambda}\right),

can obtain a Œ¥ùõø\delta-accurate solution ‚Äñùê∞t‚àíùê∞ùíü,Œª‚Äñ‚â§Œ¥normsubscriptùê∞ùë°subscriptùê∞ùíüùúÜùõø\|{\boldsymbol{w}}_{t}-{\boldsymbol{w}}_{\mathcal{D},\lambda}\|\leq\delta without any initialization condition. Here, ùê∞ùíü,Œªsubscriptùê∞ùíüùúÜ{\boldsymbol{w}}_{\mathcal{D},\lambda} is the centralized model on ùíüùíü\mathcal{D} and ùê∞tsubscriptùê∞ùë°{\boldsymbol{w}}_{t} is the federated model trained in Algorithm 2.

Compared to Theorem 1, the above theorem removes the initialization condition. More importantly, it reduces the sketch size from MùëÄM to d~Œªsubscript~ùëëùúÜ\tilde{d}_{\lambda}, which is much smaller than MùëÄM and thus it is more practical in federated learning settings. Since the communicated local sketch square root Hessian ùöºùíüj,Œª‚àà‚Ñùk√óMsubscriptùöºsubscriptùíüùëóùúÜsuperscript‚ÑùùëòùëÄ{\boldsymbol{\Upsilon}}_{\mathcal{D}_{j},\lambda}\in\mathbb{R}^{k\times M}, the communication complexity in each iteration is ùí™‚Äã(d~Œª‚ÄãM)ùí™subscript~ùëëùúÜùëÄ\mathcal{O}(\tilde{d}_{\lambda}M). For example, supposing d~Œª‚â≥log‚Å°log‚Å°(1/Œ¥)greater-than-or-equivalent-tosubscript~ùëëùúÜ1ùõø\tilde{d}_{\lambda}\gtrsim\log\log(1/\delta) as used in (Lacotte, Wang, and Pilanci 2021) with a standard learning rate Œ¥=ùí™‚Äã(1/N)ùõøùí™1ùëÅ\delta=\mathcal{O}(1/\sqrt{N}), we obtain the sketch size d~Œª‚â≥log‚Å°(0.5‚Äãlog‚Å°N)greater-than-or-equivalent-tosubscript~ùëëùúÜ0.5ùëÅ\tilde{d}_{\lambda}\gtrsim\log(0.5\log N), which is significantly smaller than MùëÄM.

Since the generalization error Œ¥ùõø\delta and effective dimension d~Œªsubscript~ùëëùúÜ\tilde{d}_{\lambda} are relevant to the specific tasks, they are not estimated in Theorem 2. However, they are important to measure the communication complexity in federated learning. It allows to provide accurate estimates for the error Œ¥ùõø\delta and the empirical effective dimension d~Œªsubscript~ùëëùúÜ\tilde{d}_{\lambda}.

Compared with Related Work

Table 1 reports the computational properties of related work to achieve Œ¥ùõø\delta-accurate solutions. In terms of the regularized least squared loss, we compare the proposed FedNS and FedNDES with first-order algorithms, and Newton-type FL methods. FedNS applies to commonly used sketch approaches, e.g. sub-Gaussian, SRHT, and SJLT, while FedNDES only applies to SRHT. Different sketch types leads to various sketch times on the jùëój-th local machine, i.e., ùí™‚Äã(nj‚ÄãM‚Äãk)ùí™subscriptùëõùëóùëÄùëò\mathcal{O}(n_{j}Mk) for sub-Gaussian, ùí™‚Äã(nj‚ÄãM‚Äãlog‚Å°k)ùí™subscriptùëõùëóùëÄùëò\mathcal{O}(n_{j}M\log k) for SRHT and ùí™‚Äã(nnz‚Äã(œï‚Äã(ùëøj)))ùí™nnzitalic-œïsubscriptùëøùëó\mathcal{O}(\text{nnz}(\phi({\boldsymbol{X}}_{j}))) for SJLT.

Compared with first-order algorithms. Federated Newton‚Äôs methods converge much faster, ùí™‚Äã(log‚Å°1/Œ¥)ùí™1ùõø\mathcal{O}(\log 1/\delta) v.s. ùí™‚Äã(1/Œ¥)ùí™1ùõø\mathcal{O}(1/\delta). But the communication complexities of federated Newton‚Äôs methods are much higher, at least ùí™‚Äã(k‚ÄãM‚Äãt)ùí™ùëòùëÄùë°\mathcal{O}(kMt), while it is ùí™‚Äã(M‚Äãt)ùí™ùëÄùë°\mathcal{O}(Mt) for FedAvg and FedProx. The proposed FedNDES achieves balance between fast convergence rate and small communication complexity, of which the convergence rate is ùí™‚Äã(log‚Å°1/Œ¥)ùí™1ùõø\mathcal{O}(\log 1/\delta) and the communication complexity is ùí™‚Äã(d~Œª‚ÄãM‚Äãt)ùí™subscript~ùëëùúÜùëÄùë°\mathcal{O}(\tilde{d}_{\lambda}Mt).

Compared with Newton-type FL methods. DistributedNewton (Ghosh, Maity, and Mazumdar 2020) and LocalNewton (Gupta et¬†al. 2021) perform Newton‚Äôs method instead of SGD on local machines. However, they only utilized local information and implicitly assume the local datasets cross devices are homogeneous, which limits their application in FL. In contrast, our proposed algorithms communicate local sketching Hessian matrices to approximate the global one, which are naturally applicable to heterogeneous settings. More recently, there are three Newton-type FL methods:

  • ‚Ä¢

    FedNL (Safaryan et¬†al. 2022) compressed the difference between the local Hessian and the global Hessian from the previous step, and transferred the compressed difference to the global server for merging. On the theoretical front, FedNL achieved at least the linear convergence ùí™‚Äã(log‚Å°1/Œ¥)ùí™1ùõø\mathcal{O}(\log 1/\delta) with the communication cost O‚Äã(M)ùëÇùëÄO(M) per round.

  • ‚Ä¢

    FedNew (Elgabli et¬†al. 2022) used ADMM to solve an unconstrained convex optimization problem for obtaining the local update directions ùëØùíüj,t‚àí1‚Äãùíàùíüj,tsubscriptsuperscriptùëØ1subscriptùíüùëóùë°subscriptùíàsubscriptùíüùëóùë°{\boldsymbol{H}}^{-1}_{\mathcal{D}_{j},t}{\boldsymbol{g}_{\mathcal{D}_{j},t}} and performed Newton‚Äôs method by averaging these directions in the server. However, this work only proved the algorithm can converge but without the convergence rates.

  • ‚Ä¢

    SHED (Fabbro et¬†al. 2022) first performed eigendecomposition on the local Hessian and incrementally send the eigenvalues and eigenfunctions to the server. The local Hessians were recovered on the server to perform Newton‚Äôs method. The algorithm achieved sup-linear convergence with the total communications costs ùí™‚Äã(M2)ùí™superscriptùëÄ2\mathcal{O}(M^{2}).

These recent Newton-type FL methods usually admit linear convergence rates, while the proposed algorithms in this work reach super-linear convergences.

Experiments

In this section, we carry out experiments to corroborate our theoretical statements on several real-world federated datasets. We implemented our methods by utilizing the public code from (Elgabli et¬†al. 2022) which includes FedNew (Elgabli et¬†al. 2022) and FedNL (Safaryan et¬†al. 2022), while SHED algorithm was excluded due to the lack of public code (Fabbro et¬†al. 2022). The base model is a logistic regression and the algorithms update the Hessian at each iteration. We first explore the impact of sketching size on the proposed FedNS and FedNDES, and then compare related algorithms w.r.t. the communication rounds.

Following FedNew (Elgabli et¬†al. 2022), we consider the regularized logistic regression L‚Äã(ùíü,ùíò)=1N‚Äã‚àëi=1Nlog‚Å°(1+exp‚Å°(yi‚Äãùíôi‚ä§‚Äãùíò))+Œª‚Äã‚Äñùíò‚Äñ22ùêøùíüùíò1ùëÅsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùëÅ1subscriptùë¶ùëñsuperscriptsubscriptùíôùëñtopùíòùúÜsuperscriptsubscriptnormùíò22L(\mathcal{D},{\boldsymbol{w}})=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\log\left(1+\exp(y_{i}{\boldsymbol{x}}_{i}^{\top}{\boldsymbol{w}})\right)+\lambda\|{\boldsymbol{w}}\|_{2}^{2}, where ŒªùúÜ\lambda is a regularization parameter chosen to set 10‚àí3superscript10310^{-3}. All experiments are recorded by averaging results after 101010 trials and figures report the mean value. We use the optimal gap L‚Äã(ùíòt)‚àíL‚Äã(ùíò‚àó)ùêøsuperscriptùíòùë°ùêøsuperscriptùíòL({\boldsymbol{w}}^{t})-L({\boldsymbol{w}}^{*}) as the performance indicator, where we use the global Newton‚Äôs method as the optimal estimator ùíò‚àósuperscriptùíò{\boldsymbol{w}}^{*}. We evaluate the compared algorithms on public LIBSVM Data (Chang and Lin 2011). We report the statistics of datasets and the corresponding hyperparameters in Table 2, where œÅùúå\rho and Œ±ùõº\alpha hyperparameters are used in FedNew.

Convergence comparison. Figures 1 reports the convergence of compared methods, demonstrating that: 1) There is significant gaps between the convergence speeds of our proposed methods FedNS, FedNDES and the existing Newton-type FL methods, i.e. FedNew and FedNL. This validate the super-linear convergence of FedNS and FedNDES. 2) The proposed FedNS and FedNDES converge nearly to FedNewton, while FedNew and FedNL converge slowly closed to FedAvg. 3) FedNDES converges faster than FedNS and the final predictive accuracies of FedNDES are higher. 4) Even with small sketch sizes, the proposed sketched Newton-type FL methods can still preserve considerable accuracy. 5) Although our communication cost is higher ùí™‚Äã(M‚Äãk)ùí™ùëÄùëò\mathcal{O}(Mk) than FedNew and FedNL, the number of communications is much smaller, resulting in lower total communications for our methods.

Impact of sketch size on Performance Figure 2 reports the predictive accuracies versus the sketch size, illustrating that 1) A larger sketch size always leads to better generalization performance. 2) The proposed FedNS and FedNDES finally converges around the global Newton‚Äô method. 3) A small sketch size, i.e., k‚â™Mmuch-less-thanùëòùëÄk\ll M and k‚â™Nmuch-less-thanùëòùëÅk\ll N, can still achieve good performance. 4) FedNDES obtains better generalization performance than FedNS with smaller sketch size.

Conclusion

Both convergence rate and communication costs are important to federated learning algorithms. In this paper, by sketching the square-root Hessian, we devise federated Newton sketch methods, which communicate sketched matrices instead of the exact Hessian. Theoretical guarantees show that the proposed algorithms achieve super-linear convergence rates with moderate communication costs. Specifically, the sketch size of FedNDES can be small as the effective dimension of Hessian matrix.

Our techniques pave the way for designing Newton-type distributed algorithms with fast convergence rates. There are some future directions, including 1) One can employ adaptive effective dimension to effectively estimate the effective dimension of Hessian in practice (Lacotte, Wang, and Pilanci 2021). 2) We consider the sparsification for the sketch Newton update in future (Derezinski et¬†al. 2021) to further reduce the communication complexity. 3) The proposed methods and theoretical guarantees can be extened to decentralized learning (Hsieh et¬†al. 2020).

Generalization Analysis for FedNS with the Squared Loss

In the above sections, we present the converge analysis for FedNS and FedNDES, but the generalization analysis relies on the specific loss function. Here, we consider the squared loss with the RKHS and the ridge regularization, i.e. kernel ridge regression (KRR). Together with the classic integral operator theory, we derive the generalization error bound for KRR with the optimal learning rates.

The target of regression learning is to find a predictor to approximate the true regression in the RKHS
